title: Link between dementia and sport is clear and football's authorities have a moral obligation to be more proactive
text:
On the day that the Football Association and Professional Footballers’ Association appeared to congratulate themselves on funding the research that confirmed the link between dementia and the sport, it is worth recalling the response to Jeff Astle’s family when the former striker died prematurely in 2002 aged just 59 but, according to his widow, looking and behaving “more like a man of 109”.

The FA offered Astle’s family two tickets to an England friendly – and then effectively reneged on a promise to complete a 10-year study into the neurological dangers of football with the PFA distancing itself from it all at that time.
